raw_text:
Elton plays Paris charity concert
 
 Sir Elton John has performed at a special concert in Paris to raise money for the victims of the Asian tsunami.
 
 The British singer played to a 2,700-strong audience on Sunday at the French capital's Bastille opera house. The concert was also part of an attempt to bring a broader range of events to the famous venue. Money raised will go to the Fondation pour l'Enfance (Foundation for Childhood) which aims to rebuild a children's shelter in Sri Lanka. Sir Elton played hits from his vast back catalogue to a sell-out crowd which included former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing and his wife Anne-Aymone. The veteran pop star played piano accompaniment throughout the concert which lasted for three hours without an interval.
 
 He told the crowd: "Throughout the years, I've done a lot of drugs and alcohol. It's true that I was a nightmare, impossible. For the last 14 years I've been normal. Now my drug is called David" - a reference to David Furnish, his partner. The crowd, who greeted each song with a standing ovation, also included French singer Charles Aznavour and British ambassador Sir John Holmes. Sir Elton has also teamed up with Phil Collins to record a version of Eric Clapton's 1991 hit Tears In Heaven to raise money for the relief fund. A release date has yet to be set for the recording, which was organised by Sharon Osbourne.
llama3.2:1b: Sir Elton John performed at a charity concert in Paris to raise money for tsunami victims. The concert was held at the Bastille opera house and featured hits from his catalogue, including piano accompaniment. The event aimed to benefit the Fondation pour l'Enfance, which supports children in Sri Lanka.

Sir Elton played hits from his back catalogue with piano accompaniment, including a rendition of Eric Clapton's "Tears In Heaven".

The concert lasted three hours with a sell-out crowd including former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing and the wife of his former vice-president Jean-Michel Ayrault. He later teamed up with Phil Collins to record a version of Eric Clapton's "Tears In Heaven" for the relief fund, which has not been set until now.

The event also aimed to expand the venue's appeal with Phil Collins on stage for a tribute version of Eric Clapton’s Tears In Heaven. Sir Elton addressed the audience, joking about quitting drugs in favor of partner David Furnish. The concert lasted three hours without an interval, generating funds for rebuilding a children's shelter in Sri Lanka through Fondation pour l'Enfance.

tinyllama:1.1b: Sir Elton John performed at a charity concert in Paris on Sunday to help victims of the Asian tsunami disaster. The legendary British singer played to a packed audience in Bastille Opera House, and raised funds for the French Foundation for Childhood, which aims to rebuild a children's center in Sri Lanka destroyed by the disaster. Sir Elton himself performed piano accompaniment throughout the concert, which lasted for three hours without an interval. He opened with hits like "Rocket Man," "Can You Feel the Love Tonight?" and "Tiny Dancer." The crowd, many of whom were overcome with emotion, cheered and gave a standing ovation after each song. Sir Elton also teamed up with Phil Collins to record a version of Eric Clapton's 1991 hit "Teardrops in Heaven" to benefit the relief fund. A release date for the recording has not been announced yet.
tinydolphin:1.1b: Sir Elton John, a legendary British singer-songwriter known as "The Prince of Pop," took center stage at Paris's Bastille opera house on Sunday for an extraordinary charity concert to raise money for the victims of the Asian tsunami disaster. He performed to a packed audience, including former French president Valery Giscard d'Estaing and his wife, Anne-Aymone, who accompanied him with her piano skills. During the concert, Sir Elton showed that he was making amends for his drug and alcohol abuse by playing piano accompaniment without an interval. The legendary musician was also joined on stage by his partner, Charles Aznavour, and British singer-songwriter Charles Aznavour to sing a rendition of Eric Clapton's "Tears in Heaven."
